text: Heres Malcolm Clark (@TwisterFilm) to explain why its important that we defend our charitable status from this legal challenge and get back to defending LGB rights.Our Tribunal resumes on Monday so please support our legal crowdfunder if you

Our international conference session Premiered last night. Watch now to hear our wonderful panelists discuss issues like being caught between the Rock of the politics of Orban and Putin, and the Hard Place of mainstream LGBTQ+ dogma.

Our defence of our charitable status in the case brought by Mermaids continues on Monday with two days of closing arguments. Unfortunately the Crowdfunder still has quite a way to go. Please - if you can afford it - help us get to our target. Thank you!

If you watch during our Conference YouTube Premieres and live Q&A sessions, not only can you join in and chat with other supporters, but you can now also donate using the Superchat function! Mr Menno again to show you how super easy it is
Our YouTube channel now has enough subscribers to allow us to accept donations, so if you like our videos please support us using the Thanks button. easy! Heres Mr Menno to show you how

Tonight at 8pm is the YouTube Premiere of our 2022 Conference panel Fighting Homophobia Worldwide, packed with moving testimony, followed by a live Q&A with Bev Jackson at 9pm. Dont miss it! Links will be sent to

On our international panel at Conference, Isaac Mugisha reminded us that David Katoâ€™s example continues to resonate in Uganda where gay activism is a matter of life or death. The law in Uganda continues to criminalise homosexuality.

Ritchies brave talk at our Conference yesterday has been covered in the Telegraph: heard how therapists failed to examine the homophobia that he experienced, or whether his gender confusion was because I hated myself because I am gay.

Our phenomenal international panel: @Vaishax @mrderekturner @el_nagashi and Isaac Mugisha.Thank you so much for sharing your powerful words with us at Conference, and solidarity in this worldwide struggle against homophobia in all its forms.

Helen Joyce in conversation with Shereen Benjamin, Julie Bindel and Kathleen Stock, currently sharing their personal experiences of bullying, silencing and being excluded from policy debates.

And were off! Conference 2022 has started, with a welcome speech from Kate Barker. We hope everyone has a wonderful day today!
Heres another peek behind the scenes of our team working tirelessly today to get everything ready for tomorrows Conference. We cant wait!

We are so grateful to Fred Sargeant for this Conference message.Fred was at the Stonewall Riots in 1969, and the next year helped organise the march in New York that later became Pride. He reminds us lesbians, gays and bisexuals dont need anyone elses permission to organise.

The team have been working hard all day to get everything ready for our Conference tomorrow, ploughing through boxes of programmes, name badges and - most importantly - Tunnocks.We hope to see you there!

WOW! We received this message of support for our Conference from the legendary Martina Navratilova in conversation with @bindelj, and we love it so much that we couldnt wait to share it with you all Thank you @Martina, and wishing you a very happy birthday!

Wishing everyone a happy InternationalLesbianDay, and especially the Lionesses, who beat the USA 2-1 last night It is wonderful to see sport providing so much lesbian representation on the world stage!

Today seems a good day to remind our followers that we receive no gov. funding or grants. Any progress we make is built on the back of small, individual donations. If you believe weâ€™re doing a good job, please help by donating. It WILL make a difference.

Great to see our good friend Paula at our stand at Conservative conference. Paula is horrified by the push to medicalise teenagers and wished us well for our event tomorrow on gender identity services

If you are at Conservative Party Conference tomorrow, please join us at 8am in room 11b for a screening of our full interview with Dr Az Hakeem on how to improve gender identity services, with Bev, Kate, Malcolm and Eileen on hand to answer any questions.

We are in Birmingham for the Conservative Party Conference, having frank conversations, dispelling myths and raising awareness of our aims with attendees. If youre there, do feel free to come by our stall for a chat ConservativePartyconference2022

The issues we raised last year at our Conference became part of the national conversation, from cancel culture to puberty blockers. Get your ticket for this years Conference, and hear for yourself tomorrowâ€™s agenda being discussed now. October 21st

Puberty blockers for Gender Dysphoric children are a scandal. Join us at conference to see Dr Az Hakeemâ€™s film exploring the evidence against them and hear Michael Biggs dissect the history of blockers. Hereâ€™s a taster

With past gay rights campaigns risking appearing performative, we now urge the FA to go further. The fact homosexuality is illegal in Qatar means that it is precarious and dangerous to suggest that gay fans will definitely be safe without firm guarantees.

And despite not being asked, 23% volunteered that struggling with their sexuality was a factor in their transition.So on this BiVisibilityDay we question why so many of those ending up on a pathway leading to transition are bisexual.Because BiTeensArentSick 6/6

BiVisibilityDayA 2021 study which surveyed detransitioners found that 23% were bisexual.However, a further 30% described themselves as pansexual or having multiple sexualities, so we donâ€™t know for sure how many were both-sex attracted.

BiVisibilityDayA 2021 follow-up study into boys referred for gender dysphoria in Canada found that 27.8% were bisexual. This study also found that in 87.8% of cases, the dysphoria resolved over time, without medicalisation.

BiVisibilityDayStatistics on referrals to GIDS in a 2014 paper showed that 26% were bisexual.ONS estimates of bisexuality in 16-24 year olds in 2014 were only 1.3%, so referrals were roughly 20x higher than in the general population.

BiVisibilityDayFrom reading Prof Michael Biggsâ€™ paper on the history of puberty blockers we find that of the first 70 children on the â€œDutch Protocolâ€, 8.6% were bisexual.One further child did not know their sexual orientation yet.

Today is BiVisibilityDay2021 ONS estimates put the prevalence of bisexuality at 1.1% of the UK population, rising to 5.3% of 16-24 year olds.We saw yesterday that attitudes to LGB people generally had improved, but here are some stats on bisexuality specifically (thread)1/6

Todayâ€™s latest British Social Attitudes survey contains some reassuring news, showing increasing acceptance of lesbian, gay and bisexual rights. This positive finding is only possible because of the reports treatment of LGB people as a distinct group.

It is disgraceful that elected officials feel free to publicly smear Allison in the worst possible way. Sending love and solidarity
RT @Lachlan_Edi: Fred Sargeant, Craig Rodwell, Ellen Broidy snd Linda Rhodes in 1970. The four Stonewall veterans were the organising fouâ€¦

This new paper by Michael Biggs really drives home the root of our concerns with medicalising gender nonconformity. From 2000, of the first 70 adolescents to undergo the â€œDutch Protocolâ€ to block puberty, only one was heterosexual.

We are appalled by the news that Fred Sargeant - Stonewall veteran and co-founder of Pride - has been beaten and robbed at Burlington Pride, by attendees who take for granted the rights he fought for decades ago.We send love and solidarity to Fred and wish him a swift recovery.
Wonderful display of solidarity with todays @StrengthLesbian rally from the Gay Mens Network.The word Lesbian is taken.
Confirmed speakers include Kathleen Stock, Michael Biggs, Julie Bindel, Simon Fanshawe and more. Check the website for updates, and get your ticket now
Huge thanks to every single one of our supporters worldwide. We love you. And thank you to the anonymous dyke who sent these beautiful flowers. LGBAlliance LGBFreedom LGBLove

Due to insufficient time this week, our tribunal will now continue with closing submissions on November 7th and 8th. A heartfelt thank you to everyone for your support so far.Please support our legal crowdfunder if you can

The witness statement of Kate Harris, co-founder and trustee of LGB Alliance is now available here:
Thank you to Joanna Cherry MP and David Davis MP for helping draw attention to the need to preserve freedom of expression, and fostering a plurality of views. These are values worth standing up for.
The witness statement of Bev Jackson, co-founder and trustee of LGB Alliance is now available here:

Today marks three years since Magdalen Berns died, far too young, at the age of 36.She stood up bravely against the erasure and coercion of lesbians, and was a fiercely inspirational voice to so many.She is sadly missed.

Heartfelt thanks to our wonderful friends for their support on day two of our tribunal. Wish us luck!
Our Tribunal will continue this morning. For anyone trying to join remotely, please be patient. Each must be verified individually, and the clerks are doing their best.
30. We stood up for lesbians, gay men and bisexuals who refuse to be redefined in the name of gender identity ideology. Thank you for your support

We are sorry to announce that our House of Lords premiere on Saturday is cancelled. We should reflect that the lives of gay men improved immeasurably during the reign of Queen Elizabeth II and we extend our condolences to the Royal Family at this sad time.
For the first time a charity has challenged another charityâ€™s registration in court. This morning we are defending our right to form a charity exclusively around same-sex and both-sex attraction.

We are deeply sorry to hear of the death of our Queen and profoundly grateful for her long life of service. We add our voices to the millions of those, at home and abroad, giving thanks for her extraordinary contribution to public life.

29. We worked hard to gain charitable status in order to defend the rights and representation of LGB people, as enshrined in the Equality Act. We are the only UK charity focused exclusively on supporting same-sex attracted people.

28. We have been preserving history, recording interviews with those who played a profound role in early LGB activism - including Linda Bellos, Martha Shelley, and Fred Sargeant - to tell their inspirational stories first hand.
We have posted an update on our case, which starts on Friday. Please donate to our crowd justice appeal if you are able to do so.

27. We submitted evidence to the govtâ€™s conversion therapy consultation explaining sexual orientation and gender identity should be separated, warning affirmation-only approaches will harm LGB youth, & calling for mental health services for
26. We have spoken up for LGB rights and representation at protests outside Holyrood and the Senedd. Governments need to listen to the concerns of those of us who are same-sex or both-sex oriented.

Reports that Iran has sentenced two activists to death for promotion of homosexuality are incredibly disturbing. We are writing to the Foreign Office to understand the womenâ€™s situation - our govt must shine a light on any brutal, homophobic practices.

Over 150 Lib Dem party members have signed this letter coordinated by @LibVoice4Women calling for @FiLiA_charity and LGB Alliances stand bookings at the Lib Dem party conference to be restored.Thank you for your support!

25. Our belief in the power of respectful dialogue has led to meetings with politicians, Ministers and Peers from every major party. We have helped them to understand the concerns of LGB people and believe we have been successful in influencing policy.
The Lesbian Strength rally in Leeds City Square is just two weeks away - attend if you can and show your support lesbianstrengthlesbianvisibility

LGB Alliance is appalled by the attack at a Pride event in Germany which a young transman was killed after bravely intervening to defend two lesbians from homophobic abuse. Our thoughts are with the friends and family of the victim.

24. We welcomed the EHRCs measured clarification of the balancing of rights in the Equality Act, and coordinated an open letter to the UN Global Alliance of National Human Rights Institutions to show our support.

23. After the success of last years conference, were doing it again, even bigger and better - and with all our events, we commit to having a number of free and discounted tickets for those who would not otherwise be able to attend. Hope to see you there!

Weâ€™re delighted to announce the first London screening of Very British Gays (formerly Queens) an intimate portrait of the lives of gay men in a world changed beyond recognition. Join us on 10th September for the reception & story so far. Email contact@lgballiance.org.uk for info

22. We highlighted the fact that Monkeypox was primarily affecting gay and bi men when others were too timid to do so. We hope that our decision to do what was right not just what was popular may have prevented some men contracting this unpleasant disease.

21. We attended a free speech event at the House of Lords. We talked to MPs and Peers about how our right to define ourselves as same-sex attracted is under threat from those who seek to replace sex with gender.

20. We applauded the introduction of compulsory RSE in schools but campaigned against sexist, regressive, anti-LGB content. We commissioned a poll that showed only 25% of parents were aware of the nature of the curriculum.
LGB Alliance has released the following statement on yesterdayâ€™s events at Pride in Cardiff.

19. We challenged the Scottish Governmentâ€™s Hate Crime Bill on the grounds that it prohibited free speech on LGB issues. We organised a letter writing campaign to MSPs and made a submission to the Justice Committee.
Our own Kate Barker was proud to join yesterdays protest at the Kenwood Ladies Pond on Hampstead Heath, in support of single sex spaces.LetWomenSwim
18. We spoke at Holyrood to highlight our concerns that many young people with gender dysphoria are LGB. Lowering the age when they can change gender to 16 is deeply irresponsible.
RT @suzanne_moore: Police removing lesbians from Cardiff Pride.Right side of history boys?
RT @GetTheLOutUK: Whatever you are... The word is LESBIANS.gettheloutCottonCeilingIsRapeterfsPrideCymru2022
RT @GetTheLOutUK: Head of the march. Vive la lesbiennes.gettheloutCottonCeilingIsRapeterfsPrideCymru2022

17. We carried out a major survey to find out some background information about our subscribers and the issues they care about, so we can attune our services and projects to their needs. The first two charts showed the basic makeup of our supporters:

16. We knew there would be enormous interest in our Conference so we made video of all the sessions freely available on our YouTube channel, where theyve been viewed tens of thousands of times. Heres Allison Baileys barnstorming keynote address

In Australia, lesbians, gay men and bisexuals face legal erasure, as sex-based orientation is considered â€œoutdated and narrowâ€.This will leave anyone same-sex or both-sex oriented without language or legal protection.ThisIsNotADrill@

15. We were delighted to be able to show our solidarity with LGB and T people by sponsoring Uganda Pride. We continue to speak up for the marginalised in countries where same-sex attracted people are persecuted and in danger.
Another great speaker for our Conference. We are pleased to be welcoming Ritchie Herron (@TullipR) on October 21st at the QEII Centre.Get your tickets here
We are delighted that Dr Michael Biggs is joining our line-up of speakers at our Conference on October 21st at the QEII Centre.Get your tickets here

14. We have received so many emails and letters from students who felt vulnerable, employees concerned about the new homophobia, from older people who were lonely or from parents of dysphoric children, and we have responded offering practical, emotional and moral support.
Excellent news from Singapore, as Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong announces that the criminalisation of gay sex will be abolished, reversing the governments previous non-enforcement position.
13. We ran a series of webinars covering finance, politics, homophobia, health, and a celebration of LGBT History Month in the form of a brilliant comedy pub quiz.

12. We ran an open-to-all event in Glasgow highlighting our concerns about the effect on LGB people of the Scottish Governments Gender Recognition Reform Bill, and created press ads to urge additional consultation.

11. In October 2021 we ran our first national conference where, for the first time, politicians from every major party shared a platform to discuss the new homophobia that threatens LGB rights. Donâ€™t forget to get your ticket for this yearâ€™s conference!

Listen to our co-founder Bev Jackson explain why, 52 years on from the first GLF march, we are facing this fight just to be able to advocate on the basis of our sexual orientation.Please support our crowdfunder
10. We ran a campaign against the unnecessary medicalisation of LGB youth, with video vans displaying our message around London.
9. We helped set up, and continue to work with international LGB groups that share our aims to create a worldwide network. Say hello to our newest group in New Zealand.
Catch the fabulous Simon Fanshawe live at Edinburgh. Tickets available here  looking forward to the encore when he speaks at our Conference on 21 October
8. We raised concerns about the promotion of binders, hormones and surgeries to LGB children on social media when we met with the Minister in charge of the proposed Online Safety Bill.

7. We ran a stand at the Conservative Party Conference and explained to MPs and policy makers why same-sex attracted people must be allowed to organise in our own interests. We will continue to press for a presence at all major party conferences soon.
6: We urged the Secretary Of State for Defence to end the British Armyâ€™s discriminatory ban on people who were HIV positive. We were delighted when that ban was lifted on World AIDS Day.
RT @TalkTV: LGB Alliance co-founder Bev Jackson defends JK Rowling after she received death threats over her support for Salman Rushdie.â€¦
5: We challenged the redefinition of words relating to us and our lives, and created a handy glossary on our website. Check it out on our Resources page.
4: We made a film that showed the majority of children referred to gender clinics are same-sex attracted, and we alerted lawmakers and politicians to the misuse and overuse of puberty blockers.

Our thoughts this morning are with Salman Rushdie, a brave man who has dedicated his life to promoting great literature and freedom of expression. Like so many others we hope all will be well for him and we stand against the bigotry and hatred expressed in the attack.

Listen to Rhona Hotchkiss explain why LGB Alliances charitable status is so important for the representation of people who are same-sex or both-sex attracted. Dont allow LGB voices to be bullied into silence, and support our crowdfunder if you can

3: We received a grant from the National Lottery Community Fund to scope a new helpline for LGB people aged 13 - 25. It will be the only helpline specifically designed to help same-sex and both-sex attracted young people.
2: We set up a Friends network to enable our supporters to make vital social connections with likeminded people near to where they live.
1: We made a short film to celebrate the lives of older gay men and are ensuring that 30% of the tickets to the very swanky London premiere are free or discounted

With just 30 days to go before Mermaids begin their challenge to our charitable status, we will be sharing one reason every day until then showing why LGB Alliance is so needed by LGB people. (Thread)ðŸ§µ

And a big thank you to Baroness Nicholson for your kind words and unwavering support

The challenge to our charitable status by Mermaids will be heard in one month.Please listen to our Managing Director Kate Barker explain why the survival of LGB Alliance matters, and support our crowdfunder if you can

We must assume that Wickes have not understood the significance of this slogan. They cannot seriously believe that lesbians, gay men and bisexuals may not organise in our own interests without the permission of trans people.
Hugely concerning news of increasing homophobic persecution in Uganda, as the governments NGO regulatory body shuts down Sexual Minorities Uganda.

Dr Bell has frequently voiced his concerns that many young people referred to gender clinics are struggling with their sexual orientation.He warns that disrupting their puberty stops them growing up into LGB adults with no need for medicalization.
RT @zaborona_media: President Zelensky approved same-sex partnerships in Ukraine! In his official response to a public petition demandiâ€¦

At a time when it appears to be open season on women, and particularly lesbians, we stand with our lesbian sisters against all homophobic abuse, and we call on political leaders stand up and actively support them too.
Wishing a very happy birthday to the inspirational @jk_rowling for her brave and steadfast support of women and LGB people (h/t @HJoyceGender for the photo!)
RT @SarahLudford: Amazing how â€˜administrative errorsâ€™ & â€˜commercial decisionsâ€™ seem to have uniquely affected - perfectly respectable - orgâ€¦
We were pleased to be able to alert Kemi Badenoch to our concerns about the treatment of young LGB people at the Tavistock clinic GIDS.

Mermaids is taking us to court to try to strip us of our charitable status. If successful, it means important films like this will not be made. If you think thatâ€™s absurd and outrageous, please support our crowd funder now.
Children referred to the Tavistock are overwhelmingly same-sex attracted and we welcome an intervention that will enable all such factors to be considered.

Huge congratulations to @BluskyeAllison on her landmark victory today!This is a vindication for all those who, like me, object to the erasure of biological sex, of women, and of same sex attraction as material realities.

WHO and NHS have finally woken up to the threat posed by monkeypox. It has taken far too long and we still need to see more action to protect gay and bisexual men. We are writing to the Health Secretary today to urge faster distribution of vaccines.

Many LGB people were gender-nonconforming children once, and if growing up today, could easily have been taught we were really the opposite sex. Please help defend the only UK charity exclusively supporting same-sex attracted people.3/

LGB Alliance believes every child should be left alone to imagine, to play, to dress up and believe they are anything they want to be - aðŸ¦–or aâ€or aor a or aor a. Childhood is precious. Leave kids alone.2/3

Gender nonconforming children - many of whom will grow up to be lesbian, gay or bisexual adults - should not be taught they are born in the wrong body, says our co-founder @BevJacksonAuth in @TheCriticMag.1/

Yesterday, @EHRC wrote to the Scottish Government expressing concerns over plans for reform of the Gender Recognition Act.We are pleased to co-sign this joint statement today in support of the EHRCs stance, and urge @scotgov to reconsider.

This is an important intervention by @EHRC. It backs what weâ€™ve been arguing for months. The govt should pass a ban on gay conversion therapy but before it proposes a ban on â€œtransgender conversionâ€ it needs to define clearly what that actually means. And do proper research.
we recommend that legislation should initially focus on banning conversion therapy attempting to change a personâ€™s sexual orientation, where the evidence and impacts are clearer.We agree

Given [...] the ongoing NHS-commissioned independent review of gender identity services for children and young people led by Dr Hilary Cass OBE, we consider that these matters require further careful and detailed considerationWe agree - wait for @thecassreview

Nor does the consultation address the possible need to consider a differentiated approach in relation to sexual orientation and being transgender so as to ensure, in particular, that clinicians and therapists are not prohibited from providing appropriate careWe agree

Itâ€™s disturbing to see a â€œlesbianâ€ conference contributing to lesbian erasure. The word â€œlesbianâ€ means something. Itâ€™s about love and sex between women: female bodies, female experience. Letâ€™s celebrate that.

7./ The good news is the archive this show is part of is called, â€˜The Gay Rights Movementâ€™. Yes ..gay. Not queer. Maybe even the BBC realised using a slur word to describe films about people who faced that slur word daily would have been an insult.

6./ Later that year homosexuality was decriminalised in England & Wales. Stonewall and the GLF followed in 1969. Itâ€™s taken longer for the bigotry, these social attitudes reflected, to shift. They leave a legacy still, not least in the homophobia of some in the LGBTQ+ movement.

5./ The dire effects of the social attitudes of the time are summed up by the wife of a man who couldnâ€™t face the disgrace of a court case and killed himself. â€œPeople couldnâ€™t seem to understand how someone could be gifted, talented, loveable â€¦and also a homosexualâ€. ðŸ¤¦â€

4./ This being 1967, the journalist felt able to say â€œsome people would be appalled at the idea of seeing a homosexual doctorâ€ and asks whether parents should be worried taking their sons to him. â€œMy patients are too civilised to say such a thingâ€, the doctor replies acidly.

3./ Two great social changes collide in the next clip where the doctor lights up a cigarette as he rebuffs the idea being a homosexual man might be a disadvantage in his profession. Not at all, he says. â€œEspecially when it comes to women.â€

2./ The film-makers then track down a doctor, â€œwho is also a homosexualâ€. He confides people are often shocked gay men who are taken to court can find witnesses to their good character. â€œWhy on earth shouldnâ€™t a homosexual have a good character?â€, he rightly points out.

1./ LGB History. Itâ€™s worth reminding ourselves how far weâ€™ve come. In the @BBC archives thereâ€™s a film from 1967 that set out to â€œreveal the truth about homosexual menâ€. It opens in a gay disco, and a classic line, â€œFor many of us this is revolting: men dancing with menâ€.
RT @nmdacosta: Very glad to see MPs making their concerns known. What is being proposed could have significant unintended consequences forâ€¦
@amoozeboosh Thanks for bringing our attention to this.

17./ Self-ID is presented as a progressive reform. We can only hope Sineads testimony sows a seed of doubt about that. Were convinced the implementation of Self-ID will leave a trail of young victims, whose bodies and minds will bear the scars of a poor policy rushed into law.

16./ We were particularly grateful to the Cabinet Secretary for agreeing to meet and listen to the testimony of Sinead Watson, @ImWatson91, that hugely impressive young Scot who went through the physical transition process before concluding shed made a mistake.

15./ We didnt expect to change the Cabinet Secretarys mind. Not least since some people in her party have spread untruths about us.  But we hope she agrees with us that meeting people who have a different point of view isnt just essential in a democracy. It can be refreshing.

14./ Far from removing medical gatekeeping we believe it should be enhanced. Its in the interests of all those who suffer from gender dysphoria, which is a medical condition, that they have access to the best possible medical care and a proper chance to change their mind.

13./ We noted that the SNPs manifesto last year did not promise Self-ID and therefore the Scottish public didnt vote for it and while we would be happy to work with the Scottish govt on some sort of reform of the GRA, we are utterly opposed to Self-ID.

12./ Our rights are protected by the Equality Act (2010)  where homosexuality and bisexuality are defined in terms of attraction to the same SEX and both SEXes respectively. Self-ID would drive a cart and horse through the Equality Act, which is reserved legislation not devolved.

11./ Self-ID will make things worse. It will erode further the single sex spaces we have built for ourselves including online. Saying gay men should not discriminate against females or lesbians against males in dating is just a new style of homophobia.

10./ For LGB folks theres an added concern. If anyone can say theyre a man or a woman without any gatekeeping it undermines our right to define ourselves in relation to the biological sex we are attracted to. Young lesbians are already under pressure

9./ Yet from Ireland to Canada news emerges of problems that may cause outrage in Scotland if Self-ID is introduced. For example, supporters of Self-ID ridiculed the claims of exposure in a womens changing room in Los Angeles. Then charges were filed.

8./ Our biggest criticism of the proposed reform is that the govt can cite no research into its likely impact at all. None has been carried out. Nor has the govt commissioned any research into the impact of Self-ID in other countries. It blithely states there have been no issues.

7./ No other signifier of adulthood comes with such an expectation of medical intervention, whether surgical or hormones. We were surprised the govt seemed unaware of the social media pressure on young people to consider body modification as a form of brave self-expression.

6./ We also fear lowering the GRC age could give  transition added cachet among LGB young people. Teens often obsess about signifiers of their coming of age. This risks a GRC becoming a newly fashionable one. Yet the govt has conducted no research on this potential impact.

5./ We were glad to hear that people will be able to change their mind and have their GRC revoked. Quite how this squares with the suggestion last year that a compulsory lifetime pledge will be a key safeguard to protect women from abuse of the Self-ID process we are unsure.

4./ If later a child regrets such decisions the GRC may add to the burden of the detransition process. We noted the govts consultation suggested a pledge to live permanently in their new gender would have to be made by anyone applying for a GRC. Could this prevent detransition?

3./ We said we were already concerned about the number of teenagers in Scotland who are being allowed to take irrevocable decisions about their bodies. Self-ID could exacerbate this. If, at age 16, a kids gender identity is validated by the state it may encourage certainty.

2./ Our biggest concern is the impact of the lowering of the age when a young person can get a Gender Recognition Certificate from 18 to 16. The growing number of LGB detransitioners and desisters testifies to the fact that young people often make mistakes when they are this age.

1./ An update on Gender Recognition Reform. Earlier this week we met Cabinet Secretary @ShonaRobison and her team, who plan to bring a GR Reform Bill before the Scottish Parliament within the next few weeks. We wanted to explain why this issue matters so much to LGB people.
@GraceBrodie @MinFreerHMG Sinead is wonderful.

21./ We look forward to continuing to provide a different perspective to the govt on this important issue. Weve come a long way in just over 2 years from a fearful meeting at the Conway Hall to representing the  interests of LGB people, at the highest levels of government. END

20./ It remains unclear whether this emphasis on risks could be interpreted as an attempt to convert. This uncertainty and the potential for a law suit from a troubled young person will tragically mean fewer clinicians will be willing to assist the gender dysphoric.

19./ Our stance is resolutely against any wilful attempt to talk young people out of their convictions. But the risks of puberty blockers, a lifetime of hormones and life-changing surgery are massive. Clinicians need the freedom to emphasise that and warn of consequences.

18./ For young LGB people who feel particularly alienated from both gender stereotypes and often their bodies all this may be particularly alluring. Shouldnt it be the job of clinicians to be gatekeepers and protect these young people from irrevocable decisions...and themselves?

17./ This suggests some young people are embracing surgery for its own sake. Heres a popular influencer explaining (at 0.45) it was surgery they wanted above all. The govt should research whether Gender identity claims are increasingly being used to access body modification.

16./ And more are on the way. We are concerned that @WPATH, the World Professional Association for Transgender Health is consulting on a new chapter for its SOC8 guidelines to cover the addition of eunuchs. Does the govt really think this gender identity should be affirmed?

15./ One of these unanswered questions is how transgender will be defined in practise. We were told it will not include novel gender identities such as demi-fluid or demi-flux. But the govts own definition in its consultation would cover those identities and many more.

14./ While we expresssed strong support for the govts proposed ban on conversion therapy for sexual orientation, we argued there are so many unanswered questions about the proposed ban on transgender conversion it should press pause on that and do more and better research.

13./ We think its explained by the fact too many institutions have come to rely on a few noisy lobby groups which push poorly evidenced messages. This leads to groupthink and creates powerful disincentives for staff who want to ask uncomfortable questions or point out flaws.

12./ Yes, it can. The type of proposed ban is being shaped by interviews with 3 people whose self-selection were warned may introduce biases, whose memories may become distorted over time and may not represent current practices. We think this is a national embarrassment.

11./ The numbers of transgender or non-binary people who were interviewed for the govts research was just 6; only 3 of whom said theyd gone through conversion therapy for gender identity. Can it be true that legislation is being justified by interviews with just THREE people?

10./ The study says such accounts may not always be accurate, their memories ...may become distorted over time and their experiences may not represent current practices. As for self-selection in general? Were warned that such sampling strategies may introduce biases.

9./ The reason for such a strange finding may be that the research consisted of a tiny sample of just 30 interviews which were self-selected and relied on memories of events years ago. We know this makes the results less reliable because the small print in the study warns us.

8./ A sign the research from Coventry University may be unreliable is that a third of the respondents whod gone through conversion therapy said theyd found positive secondary benefits from the therapy such as meeting new friends. This is a distinctly bizarre discovery.

7./ Perhaps this idea, and the facts that support it, are being ignored by the govt because the research it relies on, such as a study it recently commissioned, and publicised as part of its consultation process, is so shockingly poor and biased.

6./ We want young people with gender dysphoria to get all the care they need. A minority will never change in their conviction they are trans. We wish them well. But the evidence suggests a large group of young LGB people are being wrongly diagnosed and they need protection too.

5./ Whats more around 60% of young people diagnosed with gender dysphoria... if they are allowed to go through their puberty find their discomfort with their body lessens and often disappears. Many settle into happy LGB lives.

4./ We were disappointed to learn the govt doesnt seem to be sufficiently aware of studies that show the vast majority of young people being referred to GI clinics and being prescribed experimental puberty blockers say they are same sex attracted.

3./ For 2 years weve been trying to get the govt and NHS to protect young LGB people from this sort of misdiagnosis. If the govt gets this Ban wrong it could add fuel to the fire and the 4400% increase in girls in particular being referred to GI clinics will increase even more.

2./ Our key concern is that theres a huge conversion therapy programme underway right now in the UK which the proposed Bill ignores. BBC Newsnight revealed homophobic parents and therapists often conspire to push LGB teens towards thinking they were born in the wrong body.

1./ Conversion Therapy Update. We were delighted yesterday to meet @MinFreerHMG, Baroness Stedman-Scott and the team working on the UKs proposed Ban We believe we made progress in showing how the wrong type of Conversion Therapy Ban could end up harming LGB youth. /1 of 21

8./ WorldAIDSDay2021 is a time to remind ourselves of the terror, trauma and pain of the epidemic of the 1980s and 90s; and to commemorate the lives of those many dear friends and relatives we lost. We will remember them.Weve come so far. But there is still much to do.

7./ Today, in sub-Saharan Africa, 1.8 million people with HIV are younger than 15 years old and in South Africa an estimated 26% of women live with HIV, compared to around 15% of men. This is just one of many charities trying to help on the ground.

6./ @ALLIANCELGB pays tribute to the scientists and doctors who made this possible; and the activists who demanded greater access to treatment. But we should never forget that, before this success, AIDS took the lives of 32 million people and 38 million still live with HIV.

5./ We celebrate the fact that today the prognosis for someone newly infected with HIV, who has access to HAART, is no different from the general population. @NHSuk says HIV is a long term health condition which is now very easy to manage. Thats an incredible achievement.

4./ All this is due to one of the triumphs of modern medical science: HAART (Highly Active Antiretroviral Therapy) which essentially prevents someone with HIV being infectious. 40 years after the first reported cases of AIDS by @CDCgov, this isnt the only reason for optimism.

3./ In our letter to the MoD we pointed out that since 2013 doctors and dentists with HIV have been able to conduct invasive procedures and the @UK_CAA in 2019 lifted the ban on HIV positive pilots, since they present no additional risk compared to other civilian pilots.

2./ Today in @LesbianGayNews we said, Those who are HIV positive are no less patriotic than other Brits and it would be a powerful symbol of their acceptance as full citizens that they should be able to serve their country like anyone elseâ€.

1./ On WorldAIDSDay we welcome the UK governments new HIV Action Plan and the decision by the Ministry of Defence @DefenceHQ to allow new recruits to the armed forces who have HIV. We recently wrote to the MoD to urge just such a change of policy.

By a tragic irony, these proposals could lead to thousands of young LGB people having their puberty derailed and being pushed into lifelong medical treatment. Far from stopping gay conversion therapy, these proposals will promote it.Please Respond by December 10th./4of4 END.

We call for :- Two separate bills on sexual orientation and gender identity- On the latter bill the govt should await the findings of the Cass Review and gather much better evidence- Above all, stop the rush. Press pause to allow proper pre-legislative scrutiny/3of4

We oppose gay conversion therapy and always have. Its vile. But these proposals are deeply flawed and based on dubious research. They also try to straddle two very different subjects- sexual orientation and being transgender- that each require a very different approach. /2of4

Should the government ban Conversion Therapy? Wed love it to, but the proposed ban is badly thought through and full of contradictions that make it potentially very dangerous. To see why check our guide to how to respond to the consultation.   /1of4

@vickyjane64 Homophobic clinicians and parents are doing now exactly what they did in the 1950s and 60s: insisting homosexuality is an illness which can be â€˜curedâ€™ by medical intervention. The only difference is now itâ€™s done under a pale blue and pink flag.
7./ Heres more of Barbaras interview, by Vito Russo (of Celluloid Closet fame). Its part of a series he co-hosted called Our Time.

6./ You made me realize you gay people love each other just the way Arnold and I do, said the woman. Barbara Gittings is one of many often overlooked heroes of our movement who by their calm reasoned arguments, and their transparent goodwill helped change hearts and win rights.

5./ Barbara read aloud letters from others whod been too afraid to appear. It shocked the profession. She had a huge impact on the public too. After a TV appearance where she insisted homosexuality is good, itâ€™s right, itâ€™s natural, she was approached by a middle aged couple.

4./ Barbara played a pivotal role in removing homosexuality from the DSM in 1973; in part by convincing a gay psychiatrist to testify to a panel of the American Psychiatric Association. He did so in disguise and with a voice distorting microphone; so scared was he of exposure.

3./ Barbara devoted herself to the theme that being homosexual should not be seen as an illness. We cant progress.. until the unsubstantiated assumption of sickness...is demolished! We can only guess what shed think about the scandal of LGB teens being medicalised today.

2./ Barbara first marched in a gay picket of the White House in 1965. Here she describes an Independence Day protest in Philadelphia in 1967. Later that year shed help counter expert advice to the Defense Department that homosexuality could be cured.

1./ A History Moment and LGB Hero. When did the struggle for LGB equality begin? A key figure from well before the Stonewall Riots was Barbara Gittings. Here she is on local New York TV in 1983 recollecting the impact the Civil Rights movement had on gays in the 1960s.

If you thought the BBC report on young lesbians being sexually coerced was important then why not send them a supportive comment in the box at the bottom of the article? We did.  IStandWithLesbians

16./ As Magdalen Berns made clear in 2016 lesbians have every right to refuse pressure to widen their dating  choices. It should not need to be said but lesbians get to date on the basis of their orientation and their preference. Homosexuality isnt bigotry. IStandWithLesbians

15./ The video has been taken down but it was influential for years. As was the contention by the leading trans activist Veronica Ivy that genital preferences are transphobic. Why did critics of the BBC story not seek to distance themselves from such claims?

14./ Essentially, Dennis seem to suggest that the only acceptable reason to exclude male genitals from your sexual preferences is an experience of trauma or triggering. No. Being a lesbian -or a heterosexual man - is a sufficient and perfectly acceptable reason.

13./ What we find baffling is that none of the critics of the BBC article have bothered to deal with the examples Lowbridge cited of prominent activists effectively erasing homosexuality and bisexuality (as defined in our laws). Take this video she cites by Riley J Dennis.

12./ And when gay rapper Lil Nas joked he liked penis he was criticised for excluding men who dont have male genitals. This sort of assault on homosexuality  gaslights adults. Imagine how confusing it all seems to teen LGB people who are just discovering their sexuality.

11./ Increasingly the notion is being popularised that homosexuality- the preference for the same biological sex-  is akin to bigotry. When Myley Cyrus merely ridiculed the look of testicles in comparison with breasts she was slammed for excluding women who have testicles.

10./ Blair is the tip of the iceberg. We know how this rhetoric plays out in real life. We hear from young lesbians who are made to feel their sexual orientation -which is focused entirely on people who are biologically female- is somehow contributing to discrimination. It isnt.

9./ Young people quite rightly want to do the best they can for trans people. How might they therefore interpret Blairs suggestion: We wonâ€™t be able to say, as a society, that we are accepting of trans citizens until they are also included within our prospective dating pools?

8./ We reject this approach not least because it resembles so closely the age-old homophobia we hoped wed escaped which argued homosexuality was less valid and lesbians were somehow being difficult or unreasonable by excluding male-bodies from their sexual preferences.

7./ Dr Karen Blair argued that not to consider dating a trans person could contribute to discrepancies in mental and physical well-being within trans communities. We dont accept guilt about inequality is appropriate language to use in the context of dating. Period.

6./ At the heart of Kirkups story -and the BBCs- is the fact some proponents of gender identity say its transphobic for a lesbian to say shed never consider dating a woman with a penis. Kirkup cited an Assistant Professor of Psychology who effectively argued just that.

5./ We were founded, in part, out of anguish at hearing the sort of stories the BBC has now reported on. Were astounded anyone involved in LGBT politics could claim they knew nothing about this. Not least because @jameskirkup reported on the subject over 2 years ago, in 2019.

4./ Across what we used to think of as the gay press and beyond theres been a concerted attempt to suggest the story is fabricated and the idea of lesbians being pressured into considering sex by a small minority of transwomen is some sort of invention.

3./ The researcher behind that study, Dr Nuno Nodin, dissociated himself from the spin on his report describing it as misuse of evidence. But theres something more troubling about the reaction than arguments about samples: the suggestion the subject of the story doesnt exist.

2./ Some criticism has focused on the small sample of just 80 lesbians. But much greater claims have been made on smaller samples. One famous surveys claims that 48% of young trans people attempted suicide turned out to be based on only 27 young people.

1./ The reaction to a @BBCNews article about sexual coercion of vulnerable lesbians has been both revealing and depressing. Its fine for critics to try to find flaws but where is the empathy for the victims? No wonder  IStandWithLesbians is trending.
Each and every one of us at LGB Alliance joins the rest of the UK when we say IStandWithLesbians.Today, and always.

17./ If you want to hear more from the wonderful Daniel Kahneman here he is on how humans think in two ways. System 1 is Fast Thinking which accepts stuff youâ€™ve heard a million times (like myths about us?). Itâ€™s effortless â€˜thinkingâ€™ but very susceptible to bias.

16./ If you want to know more about us check out our website which analyses the myths about us.Or come to our conference and meet us in person. The flaws of our common human psychology can only be overcome by our shared humanity and mutual respect.

15./ We were set up to do no more than protect and defend LGB rights. The fact so many people think this is now somehow controversial tells you more about how the world has recently changed -and not for the good- than it does about us.

14./ For 2 years people have been telling the public ridiculous things about LGB Alliance. But heres the thing. If we were some sort of evil group dont you think our critics would have collected more than a mish mash of reheated claims? The simple truth is rather unexciting.

13./ Another flaw in the way we humans form judgments is our tendency to believe something if its repeated. As @veritasium reminds us this makes it familiar which makes it feel more convincing. Insert a lie at the end of the familiar statement and people will believe that.

12./ So once youve convinced yourself a bunch of liberal, refugee-rights supporting ex-Stonewall  volunteers and feminists are bigots no matter what they say, you may not listen. Indeed, when they try to convince you otherwise that may even confirm you in your negative opinion

11./ Our minds, he argues, can make judgements that are just as inaccurate as our brains seeing the wrong colour. Confirmation Bias means once someone has formed a judgement its hard to shift it. As Heidi Grant Halvorson says first impressions matter even MORE than we think.

10./ So why have the myths stuck so long? The answer may lie partly in the flaws of our shared human psychology. Daniel Kahneman won a Nobel Prize for proving our rational minds can be every bit as fallible as our senses including our visual perception.

9./ One of the biggest myths about us is were funded by right wing evangelicals. This despite the fact we support womens reproductive rights, which is anathema to them and the fact we campaign against their pernicious influence in Uganda and elsewhere.

8./ Can you remember all the celebrities and politicians lining up to say how hateful Stonewall was? No, us  neither. Without any help from Stonewall, trans people also managed to get their rights enshrined in the Equality Act. Stonewall wasnt a hate group then. Were not now.

7./ The Guide, Explains clearly what the law says organisations should do when it comes to lesbian, gay and bisexual staff, customers and service users. Yep, until just 7 years ago Stonewall was focused exclusively on sexual orientation just as we NOW are.

6./ It was as an LGB organisation that Stonewall helped get LGB rights protected in law under the Equality Act (2010). 2 years later its Guide to the Act hasnt a single reference to LGBT or Gender Identity in 32 pages. You can download it here.

5./ In the 40 pages of this 2009 pamphlet there isnt a single reference to LGBT or Gender Identity. Does that make it terribly bigoted? Its still downloadable from Stonewalls own website, so we assume not. Its also refreshingly honest about adult, human, female biology.

4./ Our critics then said we were hateful by breaking up a long-standing LGBT relationship. We didnt. Heres one of many Stonewall publications from before 2014. Its a Guide for Lesbians that gives information on How to Get Pregnant.

3./ The fact we said wed focus exclusively on LGB issues was enough to earn a label of bigotry. But there are thousands of groups that dont focus on, for example, LGB rights. Does this make them all homophobic? Only by a warped logic that says we cant focus on OUR rights.

2./ The myths began the moment we formed. Heres  @Independent saying, A new lesbian, gay and bisexual alliance group has been heavily criticised for excluding the transgender community, prompting people to label it transphobic. Evidence was there none.

1./ Whats the TRUTH about LGB Alliance? Our critics like to claim were funded by extremists and, despite the fact weve many trans supporters, that we dont support trans rights, even although we do. So WHY do so many people believe the myths?

Bev Jackson explains to @spikedonline why she and Kate Harris were forced to revive the  lesbian and gay rights movement.All LGBTQ+ groups have replaced â€œsexâ€ with self-identified â€œgenderâ€. There is nothing â€œhatefulâ€ about rejecting this change and pointing out why it matters.

@Op_Moonshot Thank you for engaging. We donâ€™t agree with you but thatâ€™s probably not a surprise to you since you appear also to disagree with @EHRC

Excellent. Just before our conference, a reminder of the wording in the Equality Act on sexual orientation. LGB people are protected in law on the basis of attraction to a personâ€™s SEX not the vaguer notion of GENDER which is increasingly conflated with gender identity.

LGB Alliance co-founder Kate Harris: â€œItâ€™s been two years in the making and we are thrilled to have a stand. We want to publicise our cause. We were set up to stand up for respectful freedom of speech.â€/1of2

14./ As you can imagine the venue costs a pretty penny, so if you cant make it do feel free to donate. Unlike some groups weve no corporate sponsors, and no government money. Were funded entirely by YOU...our loyal supporters. Tickets here:

13./ Our venue is slap bang in the centre of Londons many layered history. The first annual conference by a moderate LGB group dedicated to the protection of children and womens hard won rights is a new twist in that history. Buy a ticket and you too can say, I was there.

12./ Of course well talk about gender identity a bit (its a dogma thats a danger to LGB people) but we hope the conference will also be an opportunity to revive discussion about the subjects we all adore- art, history, music, culture, books and ideas-  in a beautiful setting

11./ Paolozzi adored science. So its a fitting happenstance that @ALLIANCELGB will be mining the depths of science (yes even biology!!) and separating fact from fiction in the shadow of his great woodblock that was inspired by two gay artists. So are you coming yet?

10./ When asked at a press conference whether the lack of female figures in his art meant he was gay, Paolozzi replied, I dont think so. Everyone is welcome to our conference, lesbians, bisexuals, straight or trans and I dont think sos. Just bring a curious mind.

9./ Inside the venue theres wonderful art too. The Scottish artist Eduardo Paolozzi was inspired to create this wooden behemoth by On This Island by gay composer Benjamin Britten who was himself inspired by a collection of poetry of the same name by gay poet WH Auden.

8./ The day will be packed but, who knows, at lunchtime before our fantastic keynote speaker @BluskyeAllison  you might have time for a stroll around the fabulous St Jamess Park or Horse Guards Parade (which hasnt changed much since Canaletto painted it in 1749).

7./ If you pop across you can see above the Great Western Door the Modern Martyrs who include Martin Luther King, Oscar Romero and Archbishop Janani Luwum (3rd from  left) killed by Idi Amin. Some argue  his murder allowed US right wing, religious homophobes to flood Uganda.

6./ Its going to be an amazing event with 4 MPs from 3 different parties, surprise guests and experts in everything from psychiatry to data collection. You have to admit the views do rather add to the glamour. Heres a little known Abbey across the road. Scrubs up nicely.

5./ In each of our main sessions there will be 4 fantastic speakers on subjects as varied as policing, the NHSs erasure of gays and how we advance LGB human rights globally. Radical uh? Heres that Kate Harris woman working out views from the stage.

4./ Drinks at the conference will be served in the HUGE hall where 400 (and counting) ticket holders can chat, buy merch, & get books signed by @bindelj, @HJoyceGender and @simonjedge before heading back for the speakers. Heres us putting finishing touches to the stage design.

3./ Later in the day we took a quick 20 min walk to visit the Churchill Estate in Pimlico, which made Powell and Mayos name in 1947. They designed it in their early 20s. It was dubbed Humane Modernism, partly because they retained the Victorian pub. Good move boys.

2./ The QEII Centre is modern architecture at its best. Powell and Moyas building is surprisingly subtle, with all those variations in the facade. Inside though the space is vast. Heres us plotting banners and decor for the day and trying not to be distracted by the views.

1./ Do you need a little pick-up after so many politicians struggled to master basic biology?  Heres a behind the scenes look at the preparations for OUR conference. Yes, us: the only LGB group in Britain that focuses solely on LGB people. For a start, heres our tiny venue.

10./ There had been endless death threats against David Kato. In November 2011, a 22-year-old, Enoch Nsubuga, was found guilty of his murder and jailed for 30 years.RIP David Kato, relentless battler against homophobia.

9./ The trauma for his friends deepened when during the funeral proceedings the local priest realised Kato had been gay and started railing against immorality and angrily demanded the mourners repent. A crowd of locals joined in the barracking.

8./ Kato was on the cover. A headline called for all 100 to be killed. Hang them; They are after our kids!! and Thousands of parents face heart-break as homos raids schools. Shortly after Kato successfully sued the magazine in 2011 he was found bludgeoned to death.

7./ This wasnt all David Kato and his brave colleagues were were up against. A year after Ssempa and Bahati began agitating for a Kill the Gays Bill, a local rag, Rolling Stone, printed the names, photographs and addresses of Ugandas Top 100 Homos.

6./ CONTENT WARNING:Not for the sensitiveIn this video, Ssempa, (a Christian pastor!) shows hardcore porn to a congregation. He uses it to claim that all gays eat excrement and take fists up to the elbow. And you thought Mary Whitehouse was extremeâ€¦

5./As rumours spread of a police raid, the gay activists fled the conference. At the end of Bahatis tirade local evangelical pastor and equally noted homophobe @martinssempa banged the table. Hes the guy who drummed up support for the Kill the Gays Bill in inimitable style...

4./ In a secret cable later released by Wikileaks the diplomat recorded how reps from the Uganda Human Rights Commission heckled and joked when Kato got up to speak. Then @dbahati the notorious US-linked politician arrived to deliver a tirade against homosexuality.

3./ Kato had warned him evangelicals had come to Uganda to preach a gospel of love intertwined with a gospel of intolerance. A founder of the countrys gay rights movement Kato spoke at a UN human rights conference in Kampala in 2009. A US diplomat later described the reaction.

2./ In interviews about the film, Williams explained Kato had told him there was an untold story of the damage American fundamentalist evangelicals are doing in Uganda and their aggressive effort to harvest young, unclaimed souls...

1./ A HERO FROM UGANDA.The struggle for equality for LGB people in Uganda has had many heroes but none perhaps greater than David Kato. It was his murder in 2011 that inspired @RogerRossWill to make his brilliant documentary God Loves Uganda
LGB rights in Uganda and how they are under attack from leading figures in the countryâ€™s political class. This is the second in our series of threads.Please RT.

12./ These links would deepen after Bahati invited 3 US pastors specialising in gay conversion therapy to Kampala in 2009. Speaking to politicians and media they urged a war on Ugandas LGB community; one thats still in full swing.

11./ Bahati is the most important link between the US evangelical Right and Ugandan politics. Here hes blessed by Ugandan homophobic pastors to wish his anti-gay bill God speed. As well discover in the next thread most of these local pastors have extensive US connections too.

10./ He warns Mills to be careful not to be caught in the act (a cheerful thought from a man who thinks that should carry the death sentence). After stopping the interview Mills says Bahati arranged for cops to speed to the hotel where he thought the crew were staying.

9./ So how homophobic is Bahati personally? Heres Scott Mills revealing to Bahati the fact he himself is gay in an interview for BBC3. Bahati says hed never have done the interview if hed known and claims it was unprofessional not to have revealed it in advance.

8./ The evangelical group that David Bahati was -and still is- closely associated with, the Fellowship, is a powerful,politically influential conservative Christian network which was the subject of Netflixs 2019 miniseries The Family. Bahati features as a character in episode 4.

7./ He claims theyd concluded it was too late for a death penalty to be introduced for homosexuality in the US but Uganda could be used as a testbed. After the Bill was hit by protests he was disappointed the US pastors disowned it. We value friendship in Africa he moaned.

6./ It was a shrewd move but disingenuous. A piece in the NY Times in 2012 revealed the idea for the anti-gay Bill and the death penalty hadnt emerged from sovereign Uganda itself but from conversations Bahati had with evangelical pastors in 2008 in the US. PHOTO

5./ The most formidable political opponent of LGB rights in Uganda is current Trade Minister David Bahati. When Western nations threatened to cut aid after he proposed an anti-gay bill, he turned the tables, defending Ugandas national sovereignty.

4./ For years the Cabinets Ethics and Integrity Minister Simon Lokodo has railed against lesbians and gays. When Stephen Fry interviewed him in 2014 he argued heterosexual child rape was preferable to consenting homosexual acts. So ethical.

3./ His colleague from guerrilla days and now the Minister for Security General Elly Tumwine is convinced Uganda is being infiltrated by a mysterious global Red Terror movement that aims to destabilise society. At 1.12 he claims its linked to LGBT.

2./ When in 2019 he signed into law a Bill strengthening penalties for homosexual acts he signalled its importance by calling a press conference and arguing homosexuality is not natural. Thats why, he said, he had to stop its promotion.

1./ UGANDA. Why did the forward march of gay rights across the world go into reverse here? A key role has been played by the government. President Musaveni regularly denounces gays. Here he is on CNN saying homosexuals are disgusting.

10./ Gay men currently live in fear in Uganda of being beaten, chased out of neighbourhoods, losing their jobs and worse. It goes without saying that there is no legal protection against discrimination. But Uganda isnt an exception. It may be a template.

9./ In a shocking video which went viral on social media a cop berates those arrested, threatens to kick them and demands to know whos the bride?. Faces have been blurred here to protect their identities. They werent blurred by the cop filming.

8./ But theres no doubt about the cloud of bigotry hanging over LGB peoples lives exemplified by the raid on May 31st when 44 people were arrested, accused of attending a secret gay engagement party. 17 men were humiliated with rectal examinations.

7./ In May a new Sexual Offences Bill was passed including an anti-gay Clause 11 which detailed terrifying new penalties such as long jail sentences for family members who dont report their gay relatives. Ministers now claim it wont be signed into law.

6./ In 2019 Bahati campaigned for a new â€˜Kill the Gaysâ€™ Bill. There was a simultaneous uptick in arrests and raids. The American Bar Association denounced the judicial homophobia and blatant misuse of legal procedures after this previous raid.

5./ The law was eventually annulled in 2014. One of the local politicians who argued for such a law is the countrys current Trade Minister, David Bahati. Here he is suggesting to Rachel Maddow (in 2010) that the penalty for homosexuality should be death. How very Christian.

4./ Lively played a key role in convincing local politicians that colonial era laws criminalising homosexual acts werent tough enough. Its widely agreed he helped inspire the passage of a new law in 2013 dubbed the â€˜Kill the Gays

3./ One of those groups is led by Scott Lively, a preacher so obsessed with gays he wrote a bizarre and widely ridiculed book in the 90s called the Pink Swastika that claimed the Nazis were really secretly led by ...butch gay men.

2./ Uganda has seen relentless police raids, media attacks and political agitation against LGB people. This brilliant documentary from 2013 traced the key role of right-wing US evangelical organisations in funding and fomenting these homophobic campaigns.

The judgment [in the @Forstater appeal] is also likely to be of significance in wider attempts to silence genderâ€“critical organisations such as the LGB Alliance, who currently face a concerted group action of trans/LGBT charities arguing their beliefs are not worthy of respect.

It is only by homogenising a single and exclusive LGBTQ identity through Gender Theory that an LGB identity can be interpreted as being anti-trans.â€/11of11This is the view of LGB Alliance, expressed eloquently and succinctly.
â€œThis is not to say that a Gender Critical LGB identity is anti-trans: outside of Gender Theory, sexual orientation and trans status are separate categories of identity./10of11

â€œFor Gender Critical gays and lesbians, transgender status is a wholly different category of characteristic from sexual orientation. The legal right (indeed necessity) of same-sex attracted people to organise together is underlined by this judgment.â€/9of11
â€œThere is an urgent need now to question the wisdom of grouping all LGBT people together as a homogenous single group, classified and defined solely by reference to Gender Theory.â€/8of11
â€œA rejection of such an interpretation of Gender Theory is an aspect of Gender Critical belief, and it is established as a protected belief by this judgment.â€/7of11
â€œIt is compounded when done in the name of LGBTQ rights: interpreted as being sold a version of your own sexuality which simultaneously erases your sexuality./6of11

â€œFor Gender Critical gays and lesbians, the insistence of homosexuality as same-gender attraction can be seen as unvarnished, base homophobia of the type that even five years ago was thought defeated, except within the most reactionary and bigoted corners of society.â€/5of11
Proponents of the Cotton Ceiling (for an explanation of this term, google it) might now be less vocal.â€/4of11
An insistence on the primacy of same gender-attraction can lead, for example, to lesbians being accused of transphobia by stating that they are not sexually attracted to males./3of11

For many, their sexual orientation is therefore incompatible with a belief in Gender Theory. Being Gender Critical is therefore a fundamental aspect of their sexual orientation, and therefore their identity./2of11

Teenagers grappling with sexual orientation or gender identity issues need appropriate care. Psychotherapists must be free to provide that appropriate care from a position of neutrality. Some tell us they are pressured to â€œaffirmâ€. That is counter to professional ethical code.

Applying coercion or other forms of pressure in an attempt to change someoneâ€™s sexual orientation or gender identity is abhorrent and we condemn it. Fortunately, whatever disgusting practices existed in the past or exist elsewhere, this no longer occurs in UK clinical settings.

It is not â€œhostileâ€ either to gays, lesbians and bisexuals or to trans-identifying people to ensure that terms are properly defined. It is not â€œhostileâ€ to anyone to define the precise nature of problems before legislating.

Unfortunately this story is generating confusion. All clinicians are required by their professional code to take a neutral position. That means neither affirming nor denying, but helping to explore the causes for distress & providing appropriate care.

It would be a tragic irony if a bill that promoters argue is intended to outlaw harm ended up instead outlawing access to the care many people tell us they need. Exploratory, and above all respectful therapeutic conversations arent harmful. They should surely be a right. /17

Weve always been against any attempt to persuade people to change their sexual orientation or gender identity. But no law should prevent young people who suffer severe gender dysphoria from accessing the benefits of gentle, humane discussions with trained professionals. /16

That doesnt mean there shouldnt be a bill to ban conversion therapy. There should be. But the need is not suddenly so urgent we should pass a law that isnt clear exactly what conversion therapy is. We must get this right and interrogate what it may mean in practise. /15

We dont doubt the vast majority of the people who signed the petition that triggered this debate had good intentions. They thought they were protecting the rights of gay people. But in truth the number of people on the receiving end of gay conversion in the UK is tiny. /14
